newsitem.title: USA: Emerging market debts mixed in pre-holiday trade.
newsitem.headline: Emerging market debts mixed in pre-holiday trade.

text.p: Latin American debts were mixed in a brief trading session ahead of the three-day U.S. Veterans Day holiday weekend.
The Public Securities Association recommended that U.S. Treasury and related markets close at 1400 EST/1900 GMT on Friday. The markets will stay closed on Monday and trading resumes on Tuesday.
Traders said most of the activities in the morning were related to switching out of Brazil and, to a less extent, Argentina into Mexico.
Soft Treasury prices sapped some energy out of the market, but without overt impact, they said.
U.S. investors apparently warmed to Mexico after Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz unveiled the 1997 budget guidelines.
Arturo Porzecanski, chief economist of Americas at ING Baring, said the numbers were by and large in line with expectations.
The 15-percent annual inflation projection is slightly lower than his firm's 17 percent, he said.

The exchange rate assumption of 8.53 pesos per dollar for 1997 was "a bit on the bearish side," but the market took it in stride, said Tulio Vera, emerging market fixed income strategist at Bear Stearns.
At 1400 EST/1900 GMT, Mexican pars MX625L19=RR were 1/8 lower at 71-3/4 bid and the UMS-26 MXUMS=RR bonds were 1/4 lower at 102-1/4.
In a market adjusting to slipping Treasuries, Brazil bore most of the brunt, said a Brady trader, noting that the stalled reform and deteriorating trade deficits were persistent worries.
Brazil's "C" bonds BR8D14=RR were 7/8 weaker at 70-3/8.
Trading in other emerging market debts was muted. Debt prices of Russia all maintained a firm tone inspite the U.S. Treasuries.
Russian Vneshekonombank dollar loans RUVNUSLNS=RR were unchanged at 78-3/4 and Ministry of Finance 3 RU3E99=RR were 3/8 firmer at 81-7/8.
